report_title: Electric Vehicle Charging Stations in the US
executive_summary: Electric vehicle charging stations have been growing since the formation of the industry. Consumers have been increasingly adopting electric vehicles amid prominent pushes to use products that are sustainable and more environmentally friendly than traditionally fuel-operated vehicles. The growing popularity of electric vehicles has led consumers to require charging stations across the country, particularly for consumers who have to go on longer drives or road trips. As a result, major charging station companies expanded their network, further driving revenue growth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Electric Vehicle Sales on the Rise
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Hybrid and electric vehicle manufacturing (IBISWorld report OD4516) revenue has been on the rise, representing a higher use of electric vehicles. The growing use of EV led to a significant rise in charging stations in both residential and commercial settings, as more consumers rely on these stations to charge their vehicles.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: With increasing government incentives and consumers and businesses seeking to reduce their carbon footprint, the popularity of electric vehicles is likely to soar in the United States, boosting demand for charging stations. Tax incentives and the consistent push toward environmentally friendly practices are expected to continue over the coming years, although some incentives are expected to weaken as a larger share of the population adopts EVs.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Government Assistance is Expected to Continue
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: With recent environmental concerns, the Biden-Harris Administration has been taking action to reduce carbon emissions. In November 2021, the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act was signed into law. This act provides $7.5 billion in funding for electric vehicle charging infrastructure with the goal of 500,000 chargers across the country by 2030. This act directly benefits demand for charging stations, enabling them to expand operations moving forward.

industry_definition: Electric vehicle charging stations manufacture, install and operate electrical vehicle charging stations and components. These stations can be of public or private use and are leveraged by companies, households and other businesses.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: High - Steady

key_trends: The rise in demand for electric vehicles has led to a jump in charging station revenue
The Bipartisan Infrastructure Law has been driving industry growth
Federal and State governments support the implementation and adoption of EV charging stations
High initial costs prevent small charging stations from becoming profitable

market_segmentation.segment_description: Households and individual users include consumers with EVs who need to charge them at home, often overnight. These are the largest markets for charging stations, as most users need their vehicles to perform daily activities.

Businesses have increasingly been adopting EV charging stations. These can be for private or public use. Public use charging stations are installed in malls, restaurants, parking lots, hotels and other businesses. Private use charging stations can also be installed in private businesses, such as office spaces and private parking lots.
Other markets include gas stations and convenience stores, which have been slow to adopt EV charging stations due to the high costs involved.

products_and_services.product_description: Alternating current (AC) level 1 charging stations offer an estimated 5 miles of driving per hour of charging, often through a 120-volt (V) AC plug. Demand for level 1 charging stations is declining.

AC level 2 charging stations are the most commonly used by both businesses and individuals. These stations offer approximately 25 miles of driving per hour of charging. Level 2 stations remain the most popular among users.

Direct-Current (DC) Fast Charging stations enable users to drive approximately between 100 and 200 miles per 30 minutes of charging. Fast charging stations have faced the fastest growth within the industry.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: As the level of consumer spending grows, consumers are more inclined to dedicate expenditure toward the purchase of an electric vehicle. Rising consumer spending represents a potential opportunity for the industry.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region has the highest percentage of electric vehicle charging station establishments at 27.3%.
The Southeast region has the highest population percentage at 21.8%.
The West Plains region has 13.6% of establishments and 4.8% of the population.
The Southwest region has 13.6% of establishments and 11.5% of the population.
The Mid-Atlantic region has 9.1% of establishments and 13.4% of the population.
The Rocky Mountains region has 9.1% of establishments and 7.1% of the population.
The New E region has the lowest percentages for both establishments (4.5%) and population (1.8%).

basis_points.basis_description: Charging stations face high initial costs. Elevated initial and operating costs have discouraged many companies, including gas stations and convenience stores, from adopting EV charging stations.
Reliance on downstream consumers impacts buyer power. If consumers continue to use fuel-operated vehicles, demand for charging stations weakens, boosting buyer power.
On the other hand, charging station companies rely heavily on high-quality raw materials, leading to moderate supplier power.
Consumers can choose between traditional and electric vehicles. These vehicles can often have a lower initial cost and are easier to maintain.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: PURCHASES ACCOUNT FOR THE LARGEST EXPENSE
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs include the cost of electricity, which represents the largest expense for already established charging stations. Electricity is a commodity purchased for sale to the consumer, driving purchase costs high as a share of revenue. Other high purchase costs include the various machinery and equipment required to manufacture, install and maintain industry charging stations, as well as costs for network communications and technical support.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: WAGES REMAIN HIGH AMID A NEED FOR SKILLED LABOR
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wage expenses are high within this industry, mainly driven by the reliance on highly skilled workers to manufacture and install charging stations. The rise in demand for EVs, and therefore charging stations, has pushed these companies to hire more workers to keep up with demand, causing wage expenses to jump.

volatility_points.volatility_title: MACROECONOMIC CONDITIONS LEAD TO HIGHER VOLATILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: High gasoline prices during times of significant inflationary pressure have deterred consumers from using larger cars. Since electric vehicles are a fuel-efficient substitute for traditional fuel-powered vehicles, they act as a cost-saving alternative. During the early stages of the pandemic, consumer uncertainty jumped, resulting in consumers avoiding large purchases and discretionary spending.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: CHARGING STATIONS ARE INNOVATIVE AND CONSISTENTLY EVOLVING
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Charging stations consistently aim to lower charging times while expanding driving distances. This helps encourage consumers to switch to EVs, supporting the industry. Bidirectional charging is becoming increasingly popular, as it enables consumers to use their vehicles to power appliances and lights during emergencies. These capabilities are still being developed. Other convenience-added capabilities include simplifying the payment process and developing wireless charging. Significant innovation efforts take place at the battery and vehicle manufacturing level, as EV manufacturers aim to make the cars themselves more efficient.

FAQs.answer: Many companies have increased hiring and expanding their number of business locations.
